>Where's THEIR cultural impact?
Avatar. Now, if I'm being serious, I think there's a sense that some of those are classics. I'm not sure if I cared about them, though.

For me personally, Avatar feels like it could do a few things better. The antagonists didn't have to job quite so hard, and the reason for moving felt a bit lame, like it was essentially an excuse to mess around with sea life instead. It'd also be nice if we got to know Neteyam better before he died to add more weight to it. I feel like most plot threads are missing just a little something to feel complete. The aesthetic isn't quite my taste either. However I have an appreciation for passion projects, so despite these flaws I still feel interested in following the series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally watched Avatar 2 yesterday, here are my thoughts.
Visually, it was stunning. It is amazing what CGI can do today. It looked organic and they did a good job of making the scenes where humans and Na'Vi are shown together look realistic.
Unfortunately the plot was kinda lame, even lamer than the first one. They did not try to evoke the sense of awe of Pandora like the first one, this is what happens to many sequels in an established universe unfortunately.
The characters were kinda shallow and too many. But I liked Spider and the relationship with Quaritch, I also liked that they made Quaritch ever so slightly less one-dimensional, which I wish they did for all "evil" characters in this movie.
Many scenes were right up copied from the first movie. I didn't even notice the music in this movie, aside from when it was copied from the first one.
The woke agenda was also present in this movie which was annoying. Cringe female role as the superior to Quaritch, all the bad humans were white except one asian woman, the black girl from the Mori was of course the one that accepted Jakes foreign family right away while the others were sceptical, the message at the end of the movie "you were born as wood people but you are now our people" gigacringe.
Overall Avatar 2 did not get spared of the overall drop in quality of modern movies which are made for stupid people with no attention spans and can only think in black and white. But the visuals were absolutely beautiful and thus I think it is worth watching.
For Avatar 3 I would wish they would portray less characters but make them more interesing, also show the perspective from the "evil" humans and don't make it all black and white, make the plot more interesting. They should not rely on an established universe but make it seem as magical as the first movie did.
Thanks for reading my thoughts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Probably the actual worst one was the Atari building in Blade Runner 2049. At the time of the original Blade Runner, Atari was a pretty big deal so it made sense that it would be in the film, everyone thought it was a very powerful company that would last forever. But this was before the big video game crash that essentially bankrupted Atari as a company and so they're no longer around. The only reason to keep the Atari logo in 2049 is to keep continuity, which is kinda silly because it takes place like 30 years after the original Blade Runner and even in the Blade Runner universe Atari could have been shuttered in that time. So what you end up having is product placement for a company that hasn't existed in the real world for a long time.

On top of this, the movie feels the need to add a "nationalism bad" message on top of the existing fact that WWI is a walking advertisement to how bad nationalism can be.

At the end of the movie, the german officers decide to do one last attack on french positions with 15 minutes left in the war. This is not something that people on the losing side of the war do. This is something that did happen in the war- but it was done by the british, as one last "fuck you we win" kick in the teeth.

But in this movie, the demoralized loser germans decided to do it with 15 minutes left in the war, and the troops are forced to do it under threat of death (you're going to die anyway attacking enemy trenches)

The protag dies literally 2 second before the war ends in a retarded and melodramatic fashion, instead of how in the book he is wounded near the end of the war, and spends several weeks in the hospital. Then the war ends, he hears the guns go silent and after hearing that, he just fades away and dies. It's an incredibly beautiful and tragic moment, he's just had too much fighting and doesn't have the energy to life anymore.

This movie is a monstrosity made people who don't understand war. It's borderline criminal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Great battle scenes, it's budgeted well, but I feel like it should have been called something like "The 11th Hour," an expression meaning something that happens near the end, as well as symbolizing the end of the war (11th hour, 11th day, 11th month). I say this cause it has nothing to do with the book, the events are radically changed, and the characters get amalgamated and changed about.
>None of Baumer's intellectual side is shown
>Tjaden dies, stabbing himself with a fork when >>178834923. He's also portrayed as a burly peatdigger, when that was Haie Westhus's character in the novel
>Kropp is burned to death instead of losing a leg and going home
>Mueller is called "Franz" instead of Friedrich, and so I kept calling Muller "Kemmerich" throughout the film until I saw the credits. Kemmerich is absent, and the whole thing with his boots being exchanged from soldier to soldier until they die is changed to a handkerchief.
>Muller is portrayed as a ladies charming chad, which was Peter Leer's character in the book.
>Behm is a nerdy kid enthusiastic to fight, which was Muller's character in the book. Behm is supposed to be chubby and reluctant to fight, making it more tragic when he's the first to die
>Scene with the French girls is heavily reduced, in the book Baumer, Leer and Kropp get some pussy.
>Kat isn't killed by some kid in the book.
>All the characters go to war in 1917 when the war is almost over and the myth of "over by Christmas" was long past, instead of enlisting in 1914 when enthusiasm was high.
>The whole part about the boys in basic training is cut
>The scene where Baumer goes home and can't connect to anything is cut
>A whole bunch of other shit.
Basically, they removed a ton of poignant, memorable stuff that would have really made the film more moving for spectacle.

>The Volkssturm (German pronunciation: [ˈfɔlksʃtʊʁm]; "people's storm")[1][2] was a levée en masse national militia established by Nazi Germany during the last months of World War II. It was not set up by the German Army, the ground component of the combined German Wehrmacht armed forces, but by the Nazi Party on the orders of Adolf Hitler and established on 25 September 1944.[3] It was staffed by conscripting males between the ages of 16 and 60 years, who were not already serving in some military unit. The Volkssturm comprised one of the final components of the total war promulgated by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, part of a Nazi endeavor to overcome their enemies' military strength through force of will.[4] Volkssturm units fought unsuccessful futile battles against the Allied forces at the end of the war and on several occasions, its members participated in atrocities accompanied by German civilians and the Hitler Youth, which were overseen by members of the SS or Gau leaders.

Genuinely not the actual problem, the problem is that it's their main concern. Race(ie, human skin colour) means nothing in Star Wars. >>178812471
To escape the confines of his life. He wanted something more instead of simply accepting what other penguins have done for generations until their respective deaths.
Instead of following the group in their standard formation going about their normal routine, he chose a different path. He saw a wide open plain of snow with mountains on the horizon and wondered: "What's beyond the mountains?"
Then he decided to go find out. Maybe he hoped there would be a better life there or maybe he didn't care. Maybe the journey itself was already enough to make him feel more alive than he ever felt before.

I'm going to confuse you even more. Why the rights to King Kong are/were with Universal? Because out of nowhere they decided to become part of this mess. When Willis O'Brien was screwed over and his idea sold to Toho it was Universal that became part of the deal because they licensed the rights from RKO/WB. Which finally woke up Merian C. Cooper who said he and not some studio owned the rights to King Kong.
